title: require maps no longer supported at browserify/lib/wrap.js:410:15?
body:
I am getting 

```
Error: require maps no longer supported
    at Function.Wrap.require (/labs/Projects/Nodebook/node_modules/browserify/lib/wrap.js:410:15)
    at Function.module.exports.Object.keys.forEach.self.(anonymous function) [as require] (/labs/Projects/Nodebook/node_modules/browserify/index.js:158:28)
    at module.exports (/labs/Projects/Nodebook/node_modules/jadeify/index.js:53:16)
    at Function.Wrap.use (/labs/Projects/Nodebook/node_modules/browserify/lib/wrap.js:105:5)
    at Function.module.exports.Object.keys.forEach.self.(anonymous function) [as use] (/labs/Projects/Nodebook/node_modules/browserify/index.js:158:28)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/labs/Projects/Nodebook/server.coffee:55:25)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/labs/Projects/Nodebook/server.coffee:63:4)
    at Module._compile (module.js:449:26)

    at compileScript (/usr/lib/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/command.js:177:29)
```

I am trying to use jadeify. So I have something like: 

server.coffee (using ExpressJS)

``` coffee-script
browserify = require "browserify"
jadeify = require "jadeify"

bundle = browserify()
    .use(jadeify(__dirname + "/client/jade/templates"))
    .addEntry(__dirname + "/public/js/app/main.js")
app.use bundle
```

Then in main.coffee (client side, compiles to `/public/js/app/main.js`)

``` coffee-script
$ = require "jquery"
jadeify = require "jadeify"

html = jadeify "test.jade", 
    title: "Hello World"
console.log html
```

Looking at the source, its actually an error thrown, so how do I actually fix it?

title: Quiet about expressions
body:
These aren't really errors. Or, at least, we know what we're doing.

We have private modules that, at require time, let us choose whether to import submodules. This keeps server code out of the client and vice versa.

title: Added contentfilter option to bundle.
body:
This is exactly what I'm looking for WRT https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/247

I know browserify-2.0 is right around the corner, but this is super-useful for us.

Thanks!

title: Apply filters to individual files
body:
I'm trying to run source filters (using falafel, of course) over all of the modules in our Browserify bundle.

It looks like `Wrap` has support for pre-filters that would allow me to filter the source of each module, but that functionality isn't exposed through the `browserify` interface.

Is there something I'm missing? Would you like a pull request?

title: add process.argv
Add process.exit
body:
In phantomify I need process exit so I can run node programs in phantomjs and then close them once they're done with their tasks. Since browserify does not has `process.exit` I workaround it this way:

https://github.com/Gozala/phantomify/blob/master/process.js#L5-L11
https://github.com/Gozala/phantomify/blob/master/phantom-bootstrap.js#L23-L26

If you'd be ok with adding this to browserify I'd love to send pull request inn.

title: Why was middleware example removed?
body:
Tried to use browserify as middleware but discovered that example about it was removed.

I'm trying to find out why was it removed. Was browserify not usable as middleware? I'm not familiar with Github but I tried to search related issues but could not find any.

Link to commit:
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/commit/da0e807ef5daa4b590799f078082331651374e24

Anyway, I found an alternative way, using API and watch mode. This adds benefit of working with any static module/middleware.

title: IE10 - process.nextTick
CoffeeScript
body:
> Direct coffeescript support will probably go away in a major point release in favor of using --plugin too.
> @substack [#128](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/218#issuecomment-10120148)

So I've done a first pass of a `CoffeeScript` plugin: https://github.com/feisty/coffee-browserify

I'm fairly certain it needs to be installed locally into the application you're browserifying rather than being able to be loaded globally. I'm not sure why or if this is acceptable. It's up to you really.

Check it out when you get some time.

this patch adds [string_decoder](http://nodejs.org/api/string_decoder.html)

this is needed for browserifying (recent) readable-stream, which is used in scuttlebutt.

This my second Pull Request without the trash commit. The whitespace are now removed.

body: I fixed some bug that happened on windows when I tried to browserify cucumber.js. Some module kept the c:/ in their name so I chase them down. It can now browserify cucumber.js on windows successfuly.

title: Fixes issue #227 and Fixes issue #228
body:
There is some oddness in the parsing of submodules tied to the way it loads sub-modules that are relative to the module.

This fix understands if the module is a global module or one that is a sub-module.

title: Multiple bundles on a single page should use the same internal module cache
body:
This would mean that `require("dependency")` returns the same result each time.

This is mainly useful for when a library has local values which you expect to be the same like a memoization library with an internal cache

title: Require import syntax for a module that has a file a nest require to a module of the same name causes infinite loop
`var thing = require('./thing');` style requires throw Module not Found errors
body:
#### index.js

in `node_modules/test/`

```
var test = {};
test.thing = require('./thing');

module.exports = test;
```
#### thing.js

in `node_modules/test/`

```
module.exports = function thing (foo) {
  console.log("thing", foo);
}
```
#### Command

When doing `browserify -r test -o test.js` and then loading `test.js` on the page, then doing:

```
var test = require('test');
```
#### Error

I get this error:

```
Error: Cannot find module './thing'
```

Any idea what might be going on here?

title: How to know which file(s) were entry points?
body:
In Node.js you can use `require.main` to know when a file was executed directly. Is something like this possible with Browserify?

It appears `require` doesn't even exist during runtime (i assume it's parsed during compile), so is there any way to make a file know if it was the entry point?

Eg: `if require.main == module { // do stuff }`

title: Compile coffee modules with bare: true
body:
This prevents the CoffeeScript compiler from wrapping the compiled
output in an (unnecessary) closure of it's own.

title: Only bundle when the modification time changed
body: Currently, the watch reload the bundle even when only the access time of a file changes (at least on Windows). This change checks that the modification time changed.

title: Add a logger option
body: This allows to use a custom logger instead of console.

title: Fixed race condition in watch mode
body:
This pull request fixes the issues #217 and #166.
I fixed a race condition where the watch check if the file in files or entries before it is set in the array, and I force to reload renamed files.

http://gkz.github.com/LiveScript/

title: Browserify requires modified files when it should not
Feature request: Option to make the result of browserify requirable.
body:
Would you accept a patch along these lines?

in `lib/wrap.js`, line 335

``` JavaScript
    else if (self.exports.indexOf('module') >= 0) {
        src = '"browserify no follow";\n'
            + 'module.export = (function(){'
            + src
            + ';require("__browserify_process");'
            + '})();\n'
        ;    
    }
```

title: browserify exits with 0 when a dependency has syntax error.
body:
``` js
//a.js

, //syntax error

```

``` js
//b.js
require('a')
```

`browserify a.js` fails, but `browserify b.js` exits with 0, 
and will then generate weird runtime errors.

title: Fixes 205
body: Implement qs.encode for request support

title: support unescape
body:
https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/querystring.js#L108

Needed for `request` to work

title: Add option for files that should be bundled, but not parsed/walked
body:
_Despite this being the 3rd pull request for this, I promise I'm not trolling you or being a pest (on purpose at least). It was just dumb to open the request against my master and dumber still to change it to a particular commit. Hopefully using a feature branch is less dumb._

I love browserify b/c it's awesome :sparkles:, but building was being a little slow when crunching big files like jQuery, Underscore, and Backbone. Caching helps on subsequent builds, but (and maybe I'm being ocd) I _know_ those files don't need to be crawled, so I hate to waste cycles doing it.

This seems like what `ignore` would do, but that option leaves the file out of the resulting bundle. That seems like a helpful option, and folks are already using it as-is. So I'm proposing `noParse` as a complementary option to include a file in the bundle, but skip crawling its AST.

I wasn't using browserify before #90 and caching, but they seem to have made a significant difference. I can verify anecdotally that using `noParse()` helps even more, particularly on the first build.

Is this a feature you want in browserify? If not, I'll let it die. If so, I'm more than open to re-implementing it differently if need be.

Thanks, @substack!

title: make compatibility shims optional
body:
When recommending browserify to people the most common objection that I have heard is that browserify includes all these compatibility shims that they would rather leave out.

The more people that use browserify the better it will get, so what about installing those shims like this, 

``` js
//entry.js
require('browserify-compatibility') 

```

On it's own, browserify should bundle everything as naked as possible, and leave out the compatibility shims.

This would also enable people to use the compatibility layer with other bundlers!
what do you think?

title: Browserify chokes on symlinks
body:
The node_modules directory in one of my projects is actually a symlink (it is a constrain in my current dev setup). 

Browserify fails to follow through.

It is easy to work around, but cumbersome since I now have to manage libraries manually.

title: Fix bug where required cache is undefined.
node_modules logic is applied to paths with ../.. in them, with buggy results
body:
**Scenario:**

```
/x/y
/a/b/c/d
```

`/a/b/c/d` contains `require("../../x/y")`.

**Bug:**
`require("../../x/y")` should not work, i.e. it should point to nonexistant `/a/b/x/y`, but it does, i.e. it retrieves `/x/y`.

**Cause:**

The code gets into `loadNodeModulesSync("../../x/y", "/a/b/c/d")`, which eventually tries the path `/a/node_modules/../../x/y`, which is of course equivalent to `/x/y`, which does exist.

**Possible solution:**

Only apply `node_modules`-climbing logic to non-relative paths. I kind of thought there was code for this already? May investigate.

This mode would be for generating bundles intended for dropping into hostile browser environments as standalone blobs with feature detection to hook onto commonjs or amd where present.

This could probably be handled in a separate module and then just required into browserify proper.

title: Hi! I fixed some code for you!
body:
Hi!

I am migrationBot!

Did you know that `path.{exists,existsSync}` was moved to `fs.{exists,existsSync}`,  and that `tty.setRawMode(mode)` was moved to `tty.ReadStream#setRawMode()` (i.e. `process.stdin.setRawMode()`)  in node v0.8.0? Read more @[API changes between v0.6 and v0.8](https://github.com/joyent/node/wiki/API-changes-between-v0.6-and-v0.8) 

I automatically made some changes I think will help you migrate your codebase to node v0.8.0, please review these changes and merge them if you feel they are useful, If they are not you can ignore this Pull Request.

Have a Nice Day!

--[migrationBot](https://github.com/blakmatrix/node-migrator-bot)

title: Error on loading modules in the 'd:\node_modules' folder
body:
Browserify can't find my modules in the node_modules folder placed in the root of the disk.
It's due to a bug in joining 'd:' and 'node_modules'.
I use Windows 7.

title: Transitive dependencies gets inserted into bundle multiple times
body:
I have a module with a `packages.json` where the dependencies part looks roughly like this:

``` json
  "dependencies": {
    "backbone": "0.9.2",
    "backbone-relational": "0.5.0"
  },
```

Both the `backbone` and `backbone-relational` modules depend on `underscore` (npm installs this as the same version into both modules' node_modules dir).

I have an index.js containing:

``` js
require("backbone");
require("backbone-relational");
```

Using `index.js` as entry file bundles the exact same version of underscore twice.

I.e:

```
$ browserify -e index.js | grep _.VERSION
_.VERSION = '1.3.3';
_.VERSION = '1.3.3';
```

I've noticed that adding `underscore` as a dependency to the top level module, then deleting the node_modules folder and running npm install again fixes the duplication issue due to the fact that `npm install` now only install underscore in the top level node_modules folder.

Is this the indended behavior? Wouldn't it be better if browserify could figure out that a specific version of a dependency is already included in the bundle and reference it instead of inserting potentially several copies of the exact same code?

title: Form events
body: How can I call a function from an HTML Form event like onsubmit? Browserify hides all functions inside an anonymous function.

title: Using .alias for relative requires
body:
I'm trying to create localized browserify bundles, and my code looks something like this:
### /build.js

``` javascript
// build the english version
var b = browserify()
b.require("./locales/en")
b.alias("locale","./locales/en")
b.addEntry("app.js")
```
### /app.js

``` javascript
var locale = require("locale")
alert(locale.hello)
```
### /locales/en.js

``` javascript
module.exports = {
  hello: "Hello!"
}
```

but I keep getting errors like `Error: Cannot find module: "locale" from directory [blah]`... Are relative directories not supported for `.alias`, or am I doing it wrong?

title: alias existsSync to prevent v0.8 warnings
Align module-object to node's module-object
Change module caching behavior in prelude.js (fixed)
body:
This issue is an amendment to #180.

I've forgotten to add the line that loads the module from cache if present. Furthermore I'm caching the module now instead of module.exports. _This_ is actually the way nodejs does it ;).

Tests have been adjusted.

title: Change module caching behavior in prelude.js
body:
I noticed that browserify manages the module caching slightly different compared to nodejs. nodejs provides a `cache`-object attached to `require()` as described [here](http://nodejs.org/docs/latest/api/globals.html#globals_require_cache). Thus a module can decide to reload another module.

In order to write modules that run in both environments browserify should do it like node.

As you can see in the attached code it's not necessary to change a lot. Unfortunately I couldn't find a place to write tests for it, but it seems like it doesn't break the old tests.

title: Is there any plan to support browerifying DB related API
body: Is it possible to support web client DB using browser plugin or java applet technology,  and then make the web client javascript API same with the nodejs API for that DB.

title: Add 'noParse()' for files that should be bundled, but not parsed/walked.
body:
[update last pull request to specific commit rather than head]

Let me start by saying that browserify is _exactly_ what I was looking for for client-side development. I love it! Thanks for making it happen :)

It's been discussed a few times that ignore() doesn't quite do what the docs say it does. I really wanted the documented functionality, however other people seem to be using it in its current incarnation. So rather than change it, I elected to add noParse() to get the same effect, w/o any loss in functionality.

Caching and #90 seem to have helped speed things up a good bit, but it's still (understandably) a little slow w/ large files on first run & parsing unnecessary files is a large, preventable part of the reason.

It's particularly helpful when including large files (ie. jQuery, Backbone, etc) that you know don't need to be parsed at all (though also helpful w/ many small files like jQuery plugins). I can verify anecdotally that this helps speed up the processing of a small app w/ large includes a great deal, even w/o caching turned on.

It's relatively little code, but certainly a non-trivial change to functionality, plus adds CLI params, etc... I basically tried to mirror the way ignore() works as much as possible, but I'm happy to discuss/implement better ways of going about it if this isn't the best approach.

Also, I added documentation, but it probably should be cleaned up. Happy to do it, just need some suggestions on how to make it better.

title: regression in 1.13.0 vs 1.12.0
body:
This going to be a detailed bug report, I'm afraid; more an fyi; a qunit test suite was failing all tests with 'require is undefined' after compiling with 1.13.0, where previously it was running without issue.  Have rolled back to 1.12.0, which fixed the problem.

Is there any backwards-compatibility breaking changes we should be aware of?  If so, isn't that a call for bumping the major version number?

Sorry I can't investigate more; now it works, I've gotta do the work that depends on it ;)

title: pass filename to coffescript compiler so parse errors include the filename
alternative configuration method
configurable ignore and client side swapping
body:
there is discussion about an ignore tag in #132 but the consensus is that using significant comments are ugly.

maybe a cleaner solution to this problem would be configuration in the package.json?

then you could say 

``` js
"browserify": {
  "./lib/server.js": "./lib/client.js", //use client instead of server
  "./lib/server-only.js": null //ignore this file on the client
}
```

browserify currently supports configuration of a different entry point when using browserify,
but sometimes you want more.

title: Doesn't detect relative paths on Windows
Missing some concepts
body:
Hi,

I think I'm missing some concepts on how browserify works. I'm trying to browserify felixge's node-mysql which he says is somewhat possible (https://github.com/felixge/node-mysql/issues/219).

So I went off and ran

```
browserify -r mysql -o bundle.js
```

Where mysql is the name of the module but when I looked at the code generated into bundle.js it had no reference to mysql in there. Suggestion what I did wrong? Can you give a walk through on I'm supposed to do. I did try to follow the recipes.

Thanks

title: fixed entry and require options priority
body:
This fixes missing alias if using:

```
browserify.bundle({
    require : {alias:"real"},
    entry: 'file'
})
```

title: Option for a root directory (eg. require('/models/user.js'); )
body:
Maybe I'm just missing something but I can't seem to find a way to achieve this.. say I have a directory structure that looks like this:

```
models/
  user.js
ui/
  account-list/
    account-list.js
```

From `account-list.js` it's really verbose writing:

```
var user = require('../../models/user.js');
```

Is there any option I can pass through to have the path to resolve to:

```
var user = require('/models/user.js');
```

Otherwise, is there any workaround you can think of? Perhaps using aliases...

Thanks!
Matt

title: Added jade support
Added jade support
when cache: true, appends entry.js twice.
body:
I'm seeing browserify append and require the entry.js file twice when in cache mode.

needless to say, this is causing unexpected behaviour.

although it works fine when not in cache mode.

title: watch broken on OSX 10.7 platform (maybe others?)
body:
long story short, changes to files being watched by browserify aren't getting picked up, and at least on my machine they actually resulted in a busted bundle being built (though I didn't dig into that).

The issue was introduced 3 days ago when node-browserify switched from using fs.watchFile (polling fstat) to fs.watch (native OS features) in order to make progress towards Windows support.  fs.watch has a number of peculiarities associated with it, some of which (including the one that bit me -- atomic edits and the related "rename" event) are documented in this node issue:

https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/2062

And coffee-script's attempt at taming this beast (seems they went from watchFile -> watch (also in the name of Windows support) -> back to watchFile (and only using watch on platforms where watchFile isn't available)

https://github.com/jashkenas/coffee-script/issues/1803

Hope that helps.  Don't have time to submit a fix right now, but I wanted to make sure someone was aware.  We've worked around it by forking and reverting e76169de, 9bc881b7 and b7397663.
--Bob

title: Failing behavior of `require` method
Add 'noParse()' for files that should be bundled, but not parsed/walked.
body:
It's been discussed a few times that `ignore()` doesn't quite do what the docs say it does. I really wanted the documented functionality, however other people seem to be using it in its current incarnation. So rather than change it, I elected to add `noParse()` to get the same effect, w/o any loss in functionality.

Caching and #90 seem to have helped speed things up a good bit, but it's still (understandably) a little slow w/ large files on first run & parsing unnecessary files is a large, preventable part of the reason.

It's particularly helpful when including large files (ie. jQuery, Backbone, etc) that you know don't need to be parsed at all (though also helpful w/ many small files like jQuery plugins). I can verify anecdotally that this helps speed up the processing of a small app w/ large includes a great deal, even w/o caching turned on.

It's relatively little code, but certainly a non-trivial change to functionality, plus adds CLI params, etc... I basically tried to mirror the way `ignore()` works as much as possible, but I'm happy to discuss/implement better ways of going about it if this isn't the best approach.

Also, I added documentation, but it probably should be cleaned up. Happy to do it, just need some suggestions on how to make it better.

title: Use newer deputy so caching works/is fast.
body: See substack/node-deputy#2

title: Global method and related cli option
body:
This is a global method to let modules to be exported as global and the associated cli option. Original idea from @substack in #155 (for `Buffer`).

**Synopsis** :

Require `jquery` and let it be a global variable.

``` js
b.global('jquery')
//-> window.jquery
```

Choose the global variable name :

``` js
b.global('jquery', '$')
//-> window.$
```

Let a sub-module (a property) of `events` module be the global :

``` js
b.global('events', {sub : 'EventEmitter'})
//-> window.EventEmitter
```

Special shortcut for _Buffer_ :

``` js
b.global('Buffer')
//-> window.Buffer
```

**Cli** :

``` bash
$ browserify --global Buffer
```

also

``` bash
$ browserify --global jquery:$
```

title: out-of-date api doc?
body:
This appears to be out-of-date:

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/doc/methods.markdown#brequirefile

I got the following message when I tried using a require statement like that:

> _Error: require maps no longer supported_

I'm not entirely sure how to correct it.

title: Switch over to buffer-browserify
body:
I think that should do it.

I haven't published [buffer-browserify](https://github.com/toots/buffer-browserify) yet, I'll do it when everything is ok.

title: Fix bug in cmd.js that stopped plugins from working
body:
The line I changed was throwing an error because `id` was never defined. It seemed like it should have been `plugin` instead, and that does the trick.

However, I don't know a ton about the project source, so let me know if it shouldn't be that way for some reason.

title: Windows compatibility
body:
This supersedes #113, #125, #126, #137, and #144.

82/83 tests pass. `test/watch.js` is the failure, with "Cannot find module './a'" I am not sure what this is about.

Please consider merging. I am happy to make any changes you desire to make it more merge-able.

title: jshint errors in generated output
body:
At work we're in the process of setting up a new project environment and one of the things we were considering doing was running jshint against the rolled-up browserify output. We're getting a few lint errors when we do that, admittedly none of which are hugely serious.

Maybe running jshint/jslint on the browserify output is a stupid idea and we should just be relying on automated tests?

Or maybe a pull request addressing the lint problems would be welcomed? We're happy to contribute in that case. :)

title: Get a list of browserified file's dependencies
body:
It would be awesome to have a command line option to output the list of files which have been read by browserify to compile the output file.

Maybe a --dependencies option, which pretty much like  --verbose option, would print out the list of required file when using the -o option.

That would be helpful for people using Makefiles, as well as for [ReadyMade](https://github.com/poulejapon/readymade).

title: Add globals lazily for all modules
body:
Since `Buffer` is a global in Node.js, it would be nice if we supported that without having to modify the existing modules.

This change enables that, but does it lazily, so it is only exposed if used (to keep the output size down for those who don't need it).

title: Look for core modules in current directory (retry)
body:
Change core modules lookup to start at current directory, which is helpful via
the CLI if the `M-browserify` module for core module `M` is not a dependency of
browserify itself.

title: Look for core modules in current directory
body:
Change core modules lookup to start at current directory, which is helpful via
the CLI if the `M-browserify` module for core module `M` is not a dependency of
browserify itself.
